past_amr_experience: My experience is quite good with mobile devices, especially when it comes to cleaning robots.
interaction_1_describe: The lawnmower stopped when a man stood in front of it and then gave way for him to pass.
interaction_1_communicating_response: Evidently, the mower backed up to let the passing man pass. She made room for him to pass through.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: This behavior was important and at the same time a surprise to me, because I didn't think he would back down and make room for a passage.
interaction_2_describe: The mower drove slowly so as not to hit the man in front of it.
interaction_2_communicating_response: I want to show Kosiaka that she knows that someone is moving in front of her and she doesn't want to hit that person, so she slowed down and started moving slowly behind the person.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: This behavior was important because it ensures that the mower does not hit any person or animal moving in front of it.
interaction_3_describe: After encountering a man, the mower retreats and drives under the man's feet.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The mower, when reversing and driving up, gives a message that this person is in its driving area so that he can make room for her to pass.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: The behavior was quite important, but it wasn't very clear.
interaction_4_describe: The mower first passed the man and then started to drive under his legs.
interaction_4_communicating_response: The mower wants to show that the man is in the path of its path and I should get off it.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: I don't think it was that important because the mower could have passed the man from all sides and kept going.

past_amr_experience: I have a robot vacuum cleaner. In the past, I've also been to restaurants where the waiters are robots.
interaction_1_describe: The mower was moving to the left until it found an obstacle (a person). It stopped, went back and stopped again.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The mower is trying to communicate that noticed an object and that knows that it's not suppose to continue moving straight.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: I think so, I think that the fact it moved in the end showed that it wouldn't proceed.
interaction_2_describe: The mower started moving from right to left and when it noticed an object moving with a different velocity, it slowed down not to hit it.
interaction_2_communicating_response: The mower is communicating that he knows the object is moving and knows its velocity.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: I think so, it shows that it's aware of its surroundings.
interaction_3_describe: The mower moved from right to left. When it noticed an obstacle, it moved back and tried again to go in the same direction. Did it multiple times (move foward and back) and wasn't able to proceed with its work.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think it's trying to communicate that it noticed an object but isn't able to continue its path.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: I think so. Howerver, it won't be able to complete its task, from what is shown in the video.
interaction_4_describe: The mower starts moving from right to left. Finds an obstacle, gets around it. Returns and finds the obstacle again. This time, moves foward and back multiple times.
interaction_4_communicating_response: In this case, since the behavior was different the 2 times the mower found the object, I'm not sure if it's trying to communicate something / what motivated different behaviors.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: It is, that it noticed the other object.

interaction_1_describe: The mower goes straight but when it encounters a person, it moves backwards to let the person pass.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I think that the robot doesn't have a purpose, but is intended to step back when encountering a person suddenly.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: I think it did, it showed when an unexpected situation occured and signaled that it would change it's behaviour.
interaction_2_describe: The mower goes straight, then when finding that the object before it is moving slower, it slows down too, so as to not collide into it.
interaction_2_communicating_response: I believe that the robot is preventing an 'accident', so it slows down.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: The steady lights indicated that it was moving forward.
interaction_3_describe: The mower goes straight, and, when encountering an object, goes backwards and forwards, every time it senses the object is there still it repeats the behaviour.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The robot is preventing an accident, so it keeps going backwards and forwards.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, I think it indicates well the intentions when going back.
interaction_4_describe: The mower goes straight, and, when encountering a person, it changes it course to the side, then, when going back, it keeps going backwards and forwards in front of the person.
interaction_4_communicating_response: The robot is avoiding crashing into the person so it swerves to the side, when going back, it keeps sensing the person; so it goes forwards and backwards.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: I think the light clearly states what movement the robot does.

past_amr_experience: My friend had an autonomous robot vacuum which I tried out while at his house.
interaction_1_describe: The mower senses that there is a person approaching so it moves out of the way for the person to pass by.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I think the robot communicates a purpose clearly because it makes a big movement to get out of the way of the person. It makes a big 90 degree turn to make it clear that it is getting out of the way of the person. if it was just a small movement it would be less clear.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: I think it is important to have the lights change to a scrolling pattern as it indicates that something about its behaviour is changing.
interaction_2_describe: The mower senses that there is a person walking in front of it so it slows down to avoid hitting the person.
interaction_2_communicating_response: It is less clear than the previous example because there are no lights to indicate a change in behaviour. The movement change is also much more subtle.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: There is not change in the light behaviour, which made its intentions less clear.
interaction_3_describe: The mower senses a person/obstacle in front if it and reverses. It tries to move forward again but the obstacle is still there. It is unable to maneuver around it so the mower just moves back and forth.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The lights are flashing so there is an indication that the robot is thinking. However, it seems unable to come up with a solution and by moving back and forth multiple times it is unclear what it plans to do to get around the obstacle.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: The light helps to show that the robot is thinking about a solution, but it might be more helpful if it turns a different colour like red to show that it is trying to solve a problem and struggling.
interaction_4_describe: The mower senses a person and goes around it, but then turns back around and is trying to go towards the person but cannot so it moves back and forth.
interaction_4_communicating_response: I think that when the robot is turning the lights should indicate left and right similar to when it is moving forwards and backwards. This would help clarify its intentions and maybe improve safety.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: The lights scrolling forwards and backwards make it clear what direction the mower is going towards, but it does not help to interpret its behaviour beyond that.

interaction_1_describe: The mower moves in the direction of the person, detects them, moves back and allows the person to pass,
interaction_1_communicating_response: The behavior of the robot could be trying to communicate to the person that its going to allow them to pass.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, it indicates that its reversing its movement.
interaction_2_describe: The mower slows down to not bump into the person in front of it.
interaction_2_communicating_response: The mower isn't doing anything that can be seen by the person in front of it. It's slowing down to prevent an accident, not to communicate.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: No, the light remained the same.
interaction_3_describe: The mower wishes to pass but due to the person in front of it, it cannot, so it goes in forward and backwards to indicate its wishes.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The mower is moving forward and backwards to show the person its intention.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: The lights change when it goes forward and backwards, complementing what it wants to do.
interaction_4_describe: The mower wants the person to leave the place where they're standing, so it manages to communicate this by moving in front of them and starting to move forward and backwards.
interaction_4_communicating_response: The mower intends to move in front of the person so they (the person) can see it and move away from where they are standing.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: The lights change depending on whether its going forward or backwards, which elevates the mower's wishes.

interaction_1_describe: It functions safely as it stops when it detects a person, and moves out of their way.
interaction_1_communicating_response: Part of its purpose is to keep others safe. It flashed a few lights when it was reversing, perhaps to signal.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, it showed it was understanding the situation and reacting correctly.
interaction_2_describe: It was following slowly behind a person, with its lights on.
interaction_2_communicating_response: By following slowly, it's trying to make the person aware that they are behind them.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: The light being on would make the person in front aware of the robot behind them.
interaction_3_describe: It's more aggressive here. It is attempting to get the person to move out of its way.
interaction_3_communicating_response: It is reversing and accelerating in front of the person. It wants the person to move out of its way.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: The lights are flashing to tell the person they are in the way and should move for the robot to proceed.
interaction_4_describe: First, it stops and goes around the person. Then it turns around and starts reversing and accelerating in front of the person. It's more intimidating here.
interaction_4_communicating_response: The robot seems to want to intimidate the person, to get them to move.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: At first the light was constant as the robot moved out of the person's way. Then when it turned around and began reversing and accelerating, the lights were flashing to signal to the person to move.

past_amr_experience: I carried out prototype testing on a prestige German brand vacuum cleaning robot, using and evaluating the product over a period of 3 months at home.
interaction_1_describe: I believe the mower is completing its work cycle and parking.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I wasn't aware of any obvious signalling of intent by the robot.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: In this instance, I found the light behaviour slightly confusing as I expected the lights to go out
interaction_2_describe: The mower appears to be following it's human controller!
interaction_2_communicating_response: I couldn't make out any audio or visual signs of communication from the robot.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Only in that the light suggests the robot is in an 'active' status.
interaction_3_describe: The mower detects a blockage in front and is attempting to navigate around the block.
interaction_3_communicating_response: By reversing back and forward and slightly changing angle of direction each time coupled with lights turning to a flash mode, this indicates robot is having to assess a situation.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Assuming what I belive is occurring in terms of the robot needing to assess a situation before proceeding then the change of light pattern does complement the behaviour.
interaction_4_describe: The robot has been summoned by it's human and has come running as if a pet dog! Now it is waiting further instruction.
interaction_4_communicating_response: By bringing itself to a stop facing the human, then reversing back & forward with flashing lights it is ltting the human now it is ready & waiting for further instruction.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, I believe in conjunction with the movement it is letting the human know it is awaiting instruction.

interaction_1_describe: The mower slows and then clears from the path of the approaching human
interaction_1_communicating_response: It is showing that it intends to move from the path of the human
interaction_1_light_behaviour: It was irrelevant.
interaction_2_describe: The mower slows as it approaches the human
interaction_2_communicating_response: The human looks the other way, there is nothing to communicate
interaction_2_light_behaviour: No
interaction_3_describe: The mower slows and then indicates that it wishes to continue
interaction_3_communicating_response: The mower proceeds, and backs off, and repeates, whilst flashing lights that indicate it's intentions
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, it indicated the desired route
interaction_4_describe: The mower avoids the human, then having circled around, proceeds to be unable to get past the human.
interaction_4_communicating_response: The mower is trying to get the human to move out the way
interaction_4_light_behaviour: It indicated that the human should move to one side

interaction_1_describe: The mower encountered the person in its' path and backed up to let the person pass.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The robot's action lets the person know that they can pass but it's not the robot's intention itself to convey that, it's just what the robot is programmed to do.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: It was important because it made it clear that the person could pass.
interaction_2_describe: The mower was moving faster at first but when it encountered the person it slowed down and matched the person's pace as it followed them.
interaction_2_communicating_response: I think the robot's programmed behavior is intended to reassure the person that they may walk at their own pace safely.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: It was important because it didn't put the person in danger by crashing into them.
interaction_3_describe: As the mower encountered the person it started moving back and forth from the place the person was standing.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think the mower's programming is trying to keep the mower moving without success because of the obstacle the person represents.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, the robot tried to keep moving despite the obstacle in its path showing that it has an objective.
interaction_4_describe: The mower moved the starting point and passed around the person when it encountered them in its' path and then when it turned around to return to the starting point, it encountered the person again and it started moving back and forth at the person.
interaction_4_communicating_response: I think the robot's programming is intended to make it move around the person in its' path both times but is unable to do it the second time.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: I think the fact the robot moves back and forth multiple times when it tries to go around the person in the return journey shows it's intended objective.

past_amr_experience: I employ some of them in my own home. I use an automatic vacuum robot that is programmed to move independently, an automatic pool cleaner and a little autonomous lawnmower
interaction_1_describe: the mower recognizes an obstacle and proceeds to move itself out of the person's way so that they can continue walking.
interaction_1_communicating_response: the purpose in this case would be to let the other person keep walking without being an obstacle but I do not believe it can be considered as the only reason for its behavior, therefore intentionality cannot be argued
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Not at first watch when, due to lack of familiarity with the robot, the light behavior seemed erratic, but afterwards I think it complemented well with the overall behavior of the mower
interaction_2_describe: the mower recognizes an obstacle in its path and goes to stop but, due to the obstacle starting to move on the same path of the mower, it only decelerates and keeps on the same path, mowing behind the person

interaction_3_describe: the mower moves straight down the path until it meets an obstacle, once the obstacle is recognized the mower retrocedes a bit and attempts to again move forward, but as the obstacle is still present it is forced to retrocede again. this is repeated for several rounds
interaction_3_communicating_response: the purpose of the mower would be to keep going straight down that path, so even though there is an obstacle it does not detour from its intended path and keeps attempting to go that way
interaction_3_light_behaviour: the light behavior in the video can only be seen from one side so it cannot be said for sure if it's behavior, but in the view it was shown in this video I found it to be confusing, as it seems to be signaling an intention to turn left
interaction_4_describe: the mower starts moving down a path but meets an obstacle, so it moves to go around the obstacle, keeps for a bit parallel to it and then later goes back on its starting path but in the opposite direction, where it meets the obstacle again and seems to get stuck by its presence
interaction_4_communicating_response: it seems to be attempting the need/want to go in the spot where the obstacle is, first by attempting to find a different route to it when it meets an obstacle and then, after not being able to go around it seems to be signaling its intention to the obstacle by repeatedly moving towards the spot and retroceding when met with the obstacle several times
interaction_4_light_behaviour: yes, when the robot had nothing to communicate to its surroundings the light was static but once it needs interaction from the obstacle (for it to move) it starts to signal his going forward and backwards

past_amr_experience: I have seen AMR hoovers and mowers in use.

interaction_1_describe: It detected an obstruction and moved out of the way.

past_amr_experience: My father has an autonomous vacuum cleaner for his store. I borrowed it and used it once or twice.
interaction_1_describe: The mower avoids obstacles and stops once it gets close to the person.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The robot simply stopped.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: No.
interaction_2_describe: The mower is following the person
interaction_2_communicating_response: I agree somewhat, since I'm not sure of its intention but it does seem to be following the person. Perhaps asking to be put on a charging pad?
interaction_2_light_behaviour: No, since the light barely changed.
interaction_3_describe: THe mower it approaching and then getting away from the person repeatedly.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I agree, since by moving forwards and backwards with respect to the person it must be trying to communicate something. Perhaps that it has finished its task?
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, since it shows movement.
interaction_4_describe: It first goes around the person until it faces them and then moves backwards and forwards.
interaction_4_communicating_response: I agree, for the same reason as in the previous example. It probably shows the same intention, just with the added effort of first facing the person it is trying to communicate with.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: It does communicate something, since the light starts changing once the robot faces the person.

past_amr_experience: I have used a robot vacuum cleaner at a holiday property. It was simple to use and a bit of a novelty. It seemed to clean OK and saved effort.
interaction_1_describe: Safety aware.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The mower is following its programming to avoid obstacles and is not really intending to communicate. I feel the question is attempting to apply human like qualities to a programmed machine.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: It functioned as a warning
interaction_2_describe: It slowed to avoiding driving into the person
interaction_2_communicating_response: The mower is simply following its programming to avoid driving into a person.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: It helped improve its visibility if someone saw it
interaction_3_describe: It stopped to avoid hitting the person and then reattempted to see if it could get past
interaction_3_communicating_response: It seemed to warn the person of its presence and intention to get past.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: It was a warning but could also be seen as demanding clear passage
interaction_4_describe: It took a detour behind the person and then moved in front of him
interaction_4_communicating_response: It could be seen as berating the person for being in its path whilst also trying to avoid him
interaction_4_light_behaviour: The flash was a warning and also rather demanding

past_amr_experience: We use a lawnmower at our hometown of Gyomro to mow the lawn. We have a family house with a garden, and most of the backyard part is done using this mobile robot. I think it's efficient since our garden is mostly square, so there are not many objects it has to steer aside from.
interaction_1_describe: The mower is moving in a given route until meeting an object in the way, it needs to recalibrate to steer aside from the object, or wait for the obstacle to move out the way.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The robot is demonstrating in a closed environment on how it works. Showing what happens when it meets an obstacle. It communicates using the lights.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: I think it shows that the robot is calculating the route and i think it complements the behaviour paired with it.
interaction_2_describe: The mower is slowly keeps going on it's route and recognizing that the obstacle in front of it is moving too.
interaction_2_communicating_response: The robot doesn't attempt to communicate with the obstacle, but it does slow down and realises that the obstacle is keeping or increasing the distance
interaction_2_light_behaviour: I dont think in this case the light behaviour is that important, the robot didnt need to communicate it could work properly, albeit a bit slowed down.
interaction_3_describe: The mower is trying to steer off from the obstacle, but it has no route to take, so it keeps going back and forth.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think the mower is trying to coummnicate and recalibrate the route, but it cant get any response from the said obstacle, and doesnt find any other route.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: I think it was important and showed that it was trying to figure out the next step and coummnicate.
interaction_4_describe: The mower in this case was able to get around the obstacle and do it's job around the route it was designed to.
interaction_4_communicating_response: I think the mower is trying to communicate after finishing almost all of it's route, but only one part of it remains where to obstacle resides. Tries to communicate with the obstacle and finish that spot too.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: I think it was a correct behaviour based on the status of the obstacle and the mower.

past_amr_experience: I owned a roomba vacuum cleaner for about 2 years, and used it extensively to clean the floors of a flat.
interaction_1_describe: when it encountered an obstacle (a human), it stopped moving, then moved out of the way, and let the person keep walking.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I think the robot showed the intention of letting the person walk in his path.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: No, I think it was pretty useless.
interaction_2_describe: The mower was moving, then encountered a walking person, and kept moving matching the person's pace.
interaction_2_communicating_response: By slowing down, the robot showed the intention of matching the pace of the human walking in front of it.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: No.
interaction_3_describe: The mower was moving, encountered a person in its path, and then moved backward, forward, then backward again, and so on and so forth.
interaction_3_communicating_response: By its repeated movement, the robot wanted the person to move out of its way, presumably to continue moving on its path.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, the lights were moving in one direction when the robot was moving forward, and in the opposite direction when it was moving backward. This, coupled with the movement, showed impatience and was useful in understanding the robot's intention.
interaction_4_describe: The mower was moving and then encountered a person facing away from it. It dodged the person, turned around to face him, and started moving forward and backward in front of the person, flashing lights.
interaction_4_communicating_response: I think it's trying to communicate something, but I'm not quite sure about what. If I had to guess, I'd say the robot was searching for the person to warn him about something dangerous.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, I think the flashing lights could mean that the robot was trying to communicate danger.

past_amr_experience: I have a robot vacuum cleaner at home and I've also worked with mobile picking robots in pharmacies.
interaction_1_describe: The mower was on its way, came across a human being, and made a reverse maneuver to get away from the person!
interaction_1_communicating_response: I think the robot intended to avoid the person, showing respect for the person
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, totally
interaction_2_describe: The mower was chasing the man and slowed down to avoid crashing into him
interaction_2_communicating_response: I think the mower intended not to hit the person by slowing down
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Yes, I do
interaction_3_describe: The mower was walking backwards
interaction_3_communicating_response: I didn't quite understand the mower's intention
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Maybe
interaction_4_describe: The mower went around the person and then went in front of the person and walked backward
interaction_4_communicating_response: I didn't quite understand the robot's intention, but maybe he wanted the person to move away
interaction_4_light_behaviour: I guess

past_amr_experience: i have seen several vacuuming robots and cleaners, recently i have seen robots that have auto clean functions and mopping functionality
interaction_1_describe: the mower detects a person and backs up to allow the person to continue walking

past_amr_experience: I've used a vacuum cleaner to clean the carpet, also when cleaning the car.
interaction_1_describe: the mower seemed to sense that someone/something was blocking its path and moved out of the way so that the person could pass.
interaction_1_communicating_response: maybe the mower could sense that the object was moving and was attempting to communicate that it could move past first before it continued on its path.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: I'm not sure, I didn't pay attention to the light behaviour.
interaction_2_describe: The mower seemed to sense that something/someone was moving in front of it and slowed down and continued to move at a slower pace because of it.
interaction_2_communicating_response: I think the mower is trying to communicate that it has been programmed not to bump into moving obstacles/to be careful of moving obstacles, so that it doesn't crash into a person for example.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: No, the light didn't seemed to change, but maybe that was because it didn't stop completely, it just slowed down?
interaction_3_describe: The mower seems to sense that something is blocking its path, it keeps moving back and forth not knowing what to do because the obstacle isn't moving out of its path.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think the purpose it's trying to communicate is that it can't move past the obstacle, it keeps flashing like it's trying to get someone's attention to say that something is wrong.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, the flashing light seemed to complement its behaviour because it seemed to be trying to convey that something is wrong because it was being blocked by something and couldn't continue working.
interaction_4_describe: The mower seemed to be able to move around the obstacle but still saw it as a problem because it couldn't clean that spot maybe.
interaction_4_communicating_response: The mower started flashing after it moved around probably to communicate that something was still blocking it's path and it wasn't able to clean properly as a result.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, it didn't flash when it went around the obstacle but it flashed the second time it encountered the obstacle because it was still blocking its path and it couldn't clean that spot properly.

past_amr_experience: I have hands-on experiences with autonomous mobile robots like lawn mowers and vacuum cleaners and understand their functions and maintenance needs.
interaction_1_describe: This mower seems to be aware of its surroundings, and it is equipped with motion sensors that detect humans and possibly objects. It is quite intelligent, as it is aware someone needs to go past it, so it creates space. this avoids collisions and allows the person to pass safely.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I think it is not trying to communicate, as it is following pre-programmed intuitions to detect possible obstacles and ensure sage and efficient navigation. However, you can argue that by the mower stopping and moving out of the way, it is signalling awareness of the presence of a human, and by moving out of the way, it demonstrates safety and avoids causing any inconvenience or harm.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, the light behaviour shown by the robot serves as a visual signal; therefore, it helps other people understand what the robot is doing and shows the actions of the robot  (as it moves back for a safe and clear passing for the human) in a clearer and safer way. it also communicates its own way to show that those actions demonstrate understanding, allowing a two-way understanding for the robot and the human.
interaction_2_describe: The mower is trailing behind the human at a slow pace. it demonstrates awareness and ensures safety by adapting its speed to the pace of humans. avoiding collision and further injuries
interaction_2_communicating_response: It may not explicitly be communicating, but but its actions of moving at the pace of the human to avoid collision and ensure safety, shows clear pure intentions to move with caution and respectively around humans within their surroundings.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Yes, the light behaviours are important because it identifies its surroundings and are also good for when, in the dark, people are aware of the robot and its intentions to ensure safety for both of them. it can also help humans, maybe allow the robot to pass by.
interaction_3_describe: The repetitive moving back and forth shows the robot is either trying to find a clearer path for the human or trying to get the human to move it of the way so it can pass.
interaction_3_communicating_response: There are two possibilities, as mentioned, either trying to find a way to clear the path for the human or for the human to move out its way so it can pass. what's been demonstrated is not clear.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: No, the moving back and forth it showing it identification of the human.
interaction_4_describe: The mower was able to identify the human and move around to avoid them, then redirects back to the human, moving back and forth to navigate a way out but gets blocked by them.
interaction_4_communicating_response: At first, it was to move around the human to find a clearer path, but ends up repositioning back to them. its not clear what the intentions were in the second act.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: at first yes to show the human in its way and asses clearer path. then no as unsure of the behaviour

past_amr_experience: I have a self-propelled vacuum cleaner that works at home at specific times of the day and is controlled by an application.
interaction_1_describe: The mower noticed the man and stopped. The fully automatic lawn mower has built-in sensors.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The robot will not come too close to the obstacle
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes. The mower is programmed so that it will not hit an obstacle
interaction_2_describe: The mower slows down and moves on as the obstacle moves.
interaction_2_communicating_response: The mower moves intelligently as the obstacle moves
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Yes, the mower intelligently slows down and starts moving as soon as the obstacle disappears from the mower's range
interaction_3_describe: When the mower notices an obstacle in its path, it slows down, reverses and starts moving again
interaction_3_communicating_response: The mower tries to signal the obstacle to move out of the way in order to continue working
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes. The mower signals with its movements that there is an obstacle in its path and with its movements it wants to move the obstacle and force it to get out of the way.
interaction_4_describe: The mower notices an obstacle in its path, avoids it, and then tries to force the obstacle to move on the other side.
interaction_4_communicating_response: By its behavior, the mower tries to force the obstacle to move
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes. The mower tries to force the obstacle to leave the area that the mower wants to mow

past_amr_experience: Every autonomous mobile robots I use (that I can think of right now) are home related. The vacuum cleaner, the lawnmower,... I am thinking of the kitchen robot Bimby but I am not sure if it qualifies as such
interaction_1_describe: The robot was moving foward in a straight line until it sensored an obstacle ahead. When it did, it stopped, backed up and redirected to a zone without obstacles.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I chose "somewhat agree" because I believe there is a lot of "little moves" it makes to communicate that it noticed the obstacle and it was preparing itself to move again but in another direction.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: A bit, but it's not my focal point of attention
interaction_2_describe: The mower did not stop this time because it noticed the obstacle was moving further away. So, in this case, kept his course but with less velocity.
interaction_2_communicating_response: Not really. It did not identify any problems so it just kept going
interaction_2_light_behaviour: The light did not catch my attention at all
interaction_3_describe: The robot identified an obstacle in front of it so it kept backing up and trying to go ahead again. It did not go for another direction this time.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I am not sure, honestly. I think it's just trying to execute its task.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: This time I looked at it the whole time and I do not. The pattern was the same throughout
interaction_4_describe: The mower was very effective in going around the obstacle. But the second time around, the activity was not the same. It kept trying to execute the same task (that was going straight in front)
interaction_4_communicating_response: I am not sure. I believe, again, it was just trying to execute it's task
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes. When it was not being able to achieve the task, the light started flickering

past_amr_experience: i'm an owner of 4 autonomous vacuum cleaners
interaction_1_describe: The mower sensed someone in its way, moved out of the person's path, and then paused
interaction_1_communicating_response: yes, the purpose is to mow within the rectangle
interaction_1_light_behaviour: yes, it's important because it helps it stand out and become more visible
interaction_2_describe: The mower sensed someone in its path, but it was not an obstacle, so it slowed its pace but continued mowing
interaction_2_communicating_response: Yes, the mower was being cautious when encountering someone in its path but sensed that it was moving and not a fixed obstacle
interaction_2_light_behaviour: yes, it helps by make it more visible
interaction_3_describe: The mower's behavior was to step back when it sensed someone blocking its path, then enter a loop where it continued to step back and proceed until it sensed the obstacle again
interaction_3_communicating_response: the implicit message sent by the mower is convey to the obstacle to move out of its way
interaction_3_light_behaviour: yes, because it helps becoming more visible
interaction_4_describe: at first it try to got around the person when it encounter from the back, but when it face in front of the person, enter a loop by stepping back and going forward hoping the person sees it and move
interaction_4_communicating_response: if the person cannot see the mower, then proceed to go around, but if the person sees the mower , the mower tries to get the person attention conveying to move out of its way
interaction_4_light_behaviour: yes, it helps to gather the attention of the person that is infront of the mower

past_amr_experience: I have used an autonomous vacuum cleaner regularly in the past.
interaction_1_describe: It is mowing forwards until it detects an obstacle, in which case it it goes a little backwards and stops. In such case its lights also flash to warn the person in case a human is the obstacle.
interaction_1_communicating_response: It is meant for automatic lawnmowing, removing the need for a human to do this task.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: I think it's useful as a warning sign.
interaction_2_describe: It keeps mowing forward, until it finds an obstacle, in which case it slows down to follow that obstacle instead of hitting it. I can only assume it stops when the obstacle does.
interaction_2_communicating_response: I don't think it communicates anything, unlike the previous one which communicates a warning through its lights.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: They are not interactive as in the previous example, but they're still useful to draw your attention to its presence.
interaction_3_describe: It mows forward until it finds an obstacle, in which case it moves slightly backwards and tries again to go forward again.
interaction_3_communicating_response: It is communicating towards the obstacle to move out of its way.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, it gives a warning and another sign for the person to move away from the mower.
interaction_4_describe: It mows forward until it finds an obstacle, in which case it goes around the obstacle to finish mowing as much area as possible in the space around it.
interaction_4_communicating_response: It is still pushing towards the person, communicating that it cannot mow the area under them.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, it's a good method of communicating a warning and a sign to move back.

interaction_1_describe: Mower stopped, backed up and let pedestrian pass it.

interaction_1_light_behaviour: Important.

interaction_2_communicating_response: Robot is programmed to slow down.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Important.
interaction_3_describe: Mower is trying to pass human.
interaction_3_communicating_response: Robot is programmed to pass humans/objects.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Important.
interaction_4_describe: Mower passed human but then turned around and got confused.
interaction_4_communicating_response: Robot is programmed to pass humans.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Important.

past_amr_experience: I have done one study with autonomous mobile robots and it was a learning expeience.

past_amr_experience: I have used a robotic vacuum cleaner in the past.
interaction_1_describe: The mower moves in a straight line, and when it encounters a human in front of it it stops, moves back and to the side, letting the human to move forward.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I think that the mower's behaviour/purpose is to indicate that it poses no obstacle to the human.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, I think that the light behaviour was important as it indicated that the mower detected the human in front of them.
interaction_2_describe: The mower was moving in a straight line, and when it encountered a human walking in front of it, it slowed down its speed in order not to collide with them.
interaction_2_communicating_response: I think the purpose / intention of the mower's behaviour was to showcase that it understands a human is in front of them and walking.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: I don't think the light behaviour was important and there were no changes to it, which makes sense if the human is not facing the mower and moving away from it.
interaction_3_describe: The mower was moving in a straight line, and when it encounter a standing human in front of it, it moved back and then tried to move forward again. Since the human was still there it stopped in front of them, and then attempted moving back and forward multiple times, always stopping when in close proximity with the human.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think the mower's purpose / intention was to show that it detected the human and moved back in order not to collide with them.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: I think the light behaviour was important in indicating the the mower detected the human in front of them.
interaction_4_describe: The mower was moving in a straight line and when it detected a human standing in front of it, it changed course in order to bypass them, then turned back towards them and stopped / moved back once it got close. It then attempted to move forward multiple times, always moving back when getting close to the human.
interaction_4_communicating_response: I think the mower's purpose / intention was to show that it detected a human, and that when this happens it will change course or move backwards from the human.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, I think the light changing when the human was detected, was important in showcasing that the detection happenned.

interaction_1_describe: Mower has been slowly moving forward and decided to move out of the human's way, by simple move backward and turn.

interaction_4_describe: the mower is able to move around the obstruction and not knock it down.

interaction_1_describe: The mower moves forward until it encounters a person. Then it stops, reverses and turns to the side.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The mower tries to communicate its behavior by sending light signals
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Lights indicate the direction in which the mower is moving
interaction_2_describe: the mower moves forward until it encounters a person ahead. Then it slows down to accommodate to that persons speed.
interaction_2_communicating_response: the lawnmower slows down to avoid a collision with the person walking in front, but it does not send any signal indicating that it is changing speed
interaction_2_light_behaviour: No, as the light behavior does not change through the sequence
interaction_3_describe: the mower moves forward until it encounters someone standing on its way. Then it moves backwards and forwards a few times.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The mower communicates its purpose via light signals
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, light signals change every time the mower changes behavior
interaction_4_describe: The lawnmower moves forward until it encounters a person in its path. That person is facing the other side. The lawnmower makes a small detour and turns to face the person. Then it goes back and forth a couple of times.
interaction_4_communicating_response: It seems like the mower can detect when someone can or cannot see it. When the person is facing the other way, the light signal does not change, but when the person is facing the mower, the light signal changes to indicate the mowers intentions.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Indeed. The light signals show the mowers intention.

interaction_1_describe: The mower went straight until it sensed a person in front of it, so it decided to go backwards to give the person space to walk, and it seems like it stopped or parked for a bit instead of choosing a new direction to go to.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I think its purpose was to communicate "I'm out of your way, and I stopped, so you can safely walk in front of me"
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, it went from having the lights on at all times to showing a pattern, probably to indicate that it changed its mode and is no longer working, until the person is out of the way.
interaction_2_describe: The mower was going at a certain speed, but detected a person walking slowly, so instead of fully stopping, it matched the speed of the person.
interaction_2_communicating_response: More than communicating a purpose, it just changed its behaviour. Maybe you can see it as communicating "I'm going to match your speed", but I don't see it trying to communicate it strongly. If it was to communicate what it's doing, maybe it would make a different sound/noise or do something different with its lights.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: No, I didn't see a difference. Maybe staying the same would signal that it's still working, but I can't be sure of that by only watching this video.
interaction_3_describe: It seems like it wants to go on a straight line rather than going around the person/obstacle, so it keeps trying to move forward, and signaling with its light that it's attempting to find a new path.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I'm not sure if it's intentional, but my guess is that it's trying to say "I want to go on a straight line so please move", however I don't know if this is intended, or if the machine got "stuck".
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, like the first video, it's signaling that it needs the obstacle or person to move before it can start working again. Also, the light indicates if it's moving forwards or backwards.
interaction_4_describe: First it goes around the person, but then it comes back to the spot that it missed, which maybe means that it doesn't want to miss any spot, and is signaling for the person to move.
interaction_4_communicating_response: Same as before, it's signaling for the person to move out of the way. However, I can't be sure if it would behave the same with a person or a wall. If it behaves like this in front of a wall, I'd assume that it got stuck and is not working as intended.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, as before it's signaling the direction it's moving, and for the person to get out of its path.

past_amr_experience: Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs) are robots designed to move through environments without human intervention, using a combination of sensors, artificial intelligence, and real-time data processing. They are capable of navigating dynamic and unstructured environments, making decisions on the fly, and performing tasks independently. My mother had a AMR vacuum cleaner, it was quite efficient in cleaning the house but it used to get stuck as time went by and one of the sensors got damaged so it was not as efficient any more.
interaction_1_describe: The mower was moving forward and it sensed that there was an object it front of it and it backed way and turned right.

interaction_2_describe: The mower moved forward at a fast pace and it slowed down as it sensed the human it front of it and it matched the humans pace as it moved at a safe distance.
interaction_2_communicating_response: The mower slowed down as is sensed the human and kept a safe distance behind it as it moved slower
interaction_2_light_behaviour: No. There was not change in the light.
interaction_3_describe: The mower moved forward towards the human and it stopped and started moving back and forth while slightly moving closer to the human.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think that the mower it trying to tell the human to move out of the way by it's behavior.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes. The mower was trying to get the human's attention.
interaction_4_describe: The mower moved forward towards the human and it turned right going around the human and facing the human in front and it started going back and forth while flashing its lights.
interaction_4_communicating_response: I believe that the mower is trying to tell the human to move out of the way by going back and forth and is trying to get the human's attention by flashing its lights.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes. The mower is trying to get the human's attention.

past_amr_experience: Besides owning an automated vacuum cleaner, i work as a civil engineer. I have worked plenty of times with automated demolition equipment, despite not operating them i know how they work and what they can do.
interaction_1_describe: The mower was moving in a straight line and stopped after sensing an obstacle in its way. Then it backed up and moved away from the path of the person that was in front of it.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I don't think it was necessarily meaning to communicate a purpose, i think the robot was trying not to damage itself or any object that appeared in front of him.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, the way it stopped and backed out of the way was important to show it is able to avoid damage and do it's work effectively.
interaction_2_describe: The mower was moving normally in a straight line until it sensed an object in front of it. It then slowed down, maintaining a certain constant safety distance to the object.
interaction_2_communicating_response: The robot is trying to show it can keep doing it's job safely, even with a moving obstacle in the way.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Yes, the way it reduced it's speed and maintained a safety distance is important to show it can safely do it's task.
interaction_3_describe: The mower was moving in a straight line until it found an object in front of it and stopped. It then started moving back and forth in front of the object.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think the robot was maybe trying to make the person if front of him move away so it could go on with it's task.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, the blinking lights could indicate there was an obstacle in the way so his movement had to change.

past_amr_experience: I was working at a warehouse, and i was part of the Inventory Scanning: The AMR is programmed to scan inventory barcodes or RFID tags.
interaction_1_describe: It detects when there's a person in front of it, and then gives the right o way to the person.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The mowers behavior of stepping aside when it detects a person can indeed be seen as an attempt to communicate a purpose. It conveys safety, intelligent navigation, user-friendliness, and technological sophistication. While the mower itself may not have the intention to communicate, its actions provide valuable information to humans about its capabilities and priorities.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: he light behavior shown by the robot is indeed important and can greatly complement its physical actions by providing visual cues that enhance communication, safety, and user interaction. By leveraging light signals effectively, robots can create a more intuitive and seamless experience for human observers and users.
interaction_2_describe: It slowed down when it detected that there's  person in front of it.
interaction_2_communicating_response: The behavior above is not indicative of the mower attempting to communicate a purpose. Instead, it's likely a safety feature designed to prevent accidents and ensure the well-being of anyone nearby
interaction_2_light_behaviour: The light behavior displayed by the robot serves as an important complement to its overall behavior, enhancing safety, facilitating human-robot interaction, improving user experience, and ensuring compliance with safety standards.
interaction_3_describe: This behavior exemplifies the intelligent and safety-conscious design of autonomous lawn mowers. By detecting obstacles and adjusting its motion accordingly, the mower ensures safe and efficient operation in residential environments, providing peace of mind to users and bystanders alike.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The mower's behavior does communicate its purpose and state, primarily focusing on safety and operational transparency. By stopping, reversing, moving forward cautiously, and stopping again, it effectively communicates its awareness of the person and its inability to proceed with its task until the path is clear. This behavior is essential for ensuring safe interactions between autonomous systems and humans.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: The light behavior of the autonomous lawn mower is indeed important and complements its physical actions by providing clear, visible cues about its status and intentions. This enhances safety, improves human-robot interaction, and ensures that the mowers behavior is easily understood by people in its vicinity. Such visual signals are essential for building trust in autonomous systems and ensuring they can operate safely and effectively in environments shared with humans.
interaction_4_describe: The mower detects that there's a person in the room.
interaction_4_communicating_response:
Upon detecting the person, the mower initiates a safety protocol to avoid any potential collision or harm.
It immediately ceases forward motion to prevent moving closer to the person.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, the light behavior displayed by the robot can be quite important and can significantly complement its overall behavior. Visual signals, such as lights, are a common way for autonomous systems to communicate their status and intentions to humans nearby.

past_amr_experience: It's mainly positive. I find them easy to use and I usually am happy with the results.
interaction_1_describe: The lawnmower recognises there is a person in front of it, and stops, moves away and stops working or is changing position.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I don't think it's trying to communicate anything. It simply stopped working once its sensor recognizes there was an object, in this case a person, in front of it.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: I think so. It's a safety measure.
interaction_2_describe: Once the mowers recognises there is someone in front of it, it adapts its speed as the person moves, in order not to bump into the man.
interaction_2_communicating_response: Once again, I don't think it's trying to communicate everything, but instead adapting its movement to the surroundings.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Yes, I do.
interaction_3_describe: The mower goes back and forth once it detects a person in front of it.
interaction_3_communicating_response: Yes, the repetitive movement of going back and forth is trying to communicate it wants to go in that direction but cannot proceed unless the person moves out of its way.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: I think it's important but I could easily become annoying for the user.
interaction_4_describe: Instead of going in a straight line, the mower goes around the person and then tries to communicate it wants to go in the direction where that person is standing.
interaction_4_communicating_response: This one is tricky, because first it goes around and then tries to reach the same spot where the person is standing by going back and forth, in an attempt to communicate to the person to move out of its way. So I'm not sure what's the thought process here if I can call it that, unless it knows it is a person and only communicate with him when they're facing each other.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, I'm thinking about how useful this could be for deaf people, just to use an example.

past_amr_experience: I have average experience with AMRs and the experience has been fairly good. Most AMRs are very efficient and get the job done quickly so that is a bonus.
interaction_1_describe: The mower moves forward but senses that there is a person in front of it and moves out of the way and dims its lights to let the person pass.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I think the mower's intention or purpose was to give the person space to pass.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, the light behaviour was important. When the mower was actively moving, it had bright lights. But when it was givig the individual a chance to pass, the lights dimmed a little.
interaction_2_describe: The mower was moving towards the individual and when it was close to re indivual, it slowed down its speed to keep a certain distance between it and the individual.
interaction_2_communicating_response: The mower's purpose was to not crash into the person and keep a certain distance between it and the individual in front of it
interaction_2_light_behaviour: I think the light behaviour was important as the lights stayed bright while the mower was actively moving.
interaction_3_describe: The mower moves back and forth in front of the individual as if to attempt to get the individual to move.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The mower is trying to bring attention of its presence to the individual and trying to get the individual to move out of its way.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: The lights complement the behaviour of the mower by staying on as it is moving.
interaction_4_describe: The mower comes up behind the individual and moves out of his way. And then it comes up again in front of the individual and moves back and forth in front of him.
interaction_4_communicating_response: The mower is trying to get the individual to move out of its way by going back and forth in front of him instead of it moving itself.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: The light behaviour was important because the lights stayed on as the mower was moving.

past_amr_experience: I use autonomous mobile robots such as my vacuum cleaner on a weekly basis.
interaction_1_describe: The mower exhibits almost human-navigating abilities, as it stops promptly before the person, then proceeds to backup and reverse.
interaction_1_communicating_response: It could be programmed to merely perform a task, the answer to which I unfamiliar with...
interaction_1_light_behaviour: The light built into the mower is very useful as it begins to flicker when it senses that is it within close proximity to an object, in this case, a person.
interaction_2_describe: The mower proceeded to move ever so slowly on a straight course/path.
interaction_2_communicating_response: The mower seems to be destined to move on its own course, provided that there are no obstacles in its way.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: As the person was not as close to the mower as he could have been, we find that the mower's light did not sense any close object proximity and so the light stayed constant as oppossed to flickering.
interaction_3_describe: The mower repeatedly moves back and forth as its path is blocked by an obstacle(the person).
interaction_3_communicating_response: It expects above stated obstacle to move out of its (the mower's) path.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Very much so, the light constantly flickering, indicates that the obstacle faced by the mower, refuses to move out of the mower's path, even though the mower continuously provides a means for the person to do so each time the mower reverses.
interaction_4_describe: The mower moved swiftly along and around the human obstacle, but then kept stopping abrubtly within close proximity of the obstacle(now facing the person). All this while the person continued to remain steadfast in his position.
interaction_4_communicating_response: It is trying to display that it has the capability to move around an obstacle; however, it cannot proceed through an obstacle/s.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Indeed, as the mower manoeuvered around the obstacle, it kept a wide enough berth, thus its lights stayed fixed, however when it repeatedly got within close proximity of the person, its lights kept flickering.

interaction_1_describe: The mower moved forward in a straight direction, then it stopped before encountering the human. It then backed up in the opposite direction for a bit, and continued to reverse to the right for a bit.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I think the mower's intention is to allowing the human to pass.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, I think the light behaviour communicates the direction of movement of the mower,and perhaps to indicate stop and go.
interaction_2_describe: The mower was moving forward at a speed, then slowed down it's speed as it approached the human.
interaction_2_communicating_response: I think the intention of the mower moving slower is so that it doesn't collide with the human when it comes a certain distance to the human.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: I think the light behaviour (the light being on) indicates that the mower is in motion.
interaction_3_describe: The mower moves back and forth with a light indicator flashing to the left as it encounters the human.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think the robot intends to communicate with the human, what direction to move out of the way.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes.
interaction_4_describe: The mower moves forward before encountering the human, then stops and moves around the human to the right. The mower then makes it's way back toward the direction of the human, then stops completely and flashes a light indicator to the right when it encounters the human again.
interaction_4_communicating_response: I think the mower intends to move over areas where grass is to be cut. In this instance, the mower first moves around the human, but as it makes its way back, it opts to stop and indicate for the human to move out the so it may move over the area where it had not 'cut'.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes.

past_amr_experience: My experience with Autonomous Mobile Robots highlights their transformative potential across various sectors. Their ability to operate autonomously and efficiently makes them invaluable assets in modern industries, driving productivity and innovation. However, successful implementation requires careful planning, integration, and maintenance to fully realize their benefits.
interaction_1_describe: very accurate and observant for any object
interaction_1_communicating_response: In my understanding, the mower, being an autonomous machine, does indeed convey a purpose through its actions. Its primary intention is to mow the lawn efficiently and effectively. This purpose is manifested in its movements, as it navigates the lawn, avoiding obstacles and cutting the grass in a systematic manner. Additionally, features such as sensors and programming contribute to its ability to fulfill this purpose autonomously, enhancing its efficiency and precision in completing the task.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, the light behavior exhibited by the mower can be important and complement its overall behavior. The fact that it is very accurate and observant of any object, coupled with its light behavior, enhances its effectiveness in fulfilling its purpose of mowing the lawn efficiently.
interaction_2_describe: able to detect any moving object
interaction_2_communicating_response: I perceive the mower's purpose as being clear and directed towards accomplishing its designated function of maintaining the lawn.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: the light behavior adds an additional layer of functionality and communication to the mower's autonomous operation, complementing its behavior and contributing to its effectiveness in accomplishing its purpose of maintaining the lawn.
interaction_3_describe: analyzing the object
interaction_3_communicating_response: his purpose is manifested in its movements, as it navigates the lawn, avoiding obstacles and cutting the grass in a systematic manner. Additionally, features such as sensors and programming contribute to its ability to fulfill this purpose autonomously, enhancing its efficiency and precision in completing the task.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: the light behavior might convey information about the mower's direction of movement or its current task, further improving its communication with its surroundings.
interaction_4_describe: analytical and observant
interaction_4_communicating_response: The mower's purpose is evident in its behavior of navigating the lawn while avoiding obstacles with precision. This purpose is inherent in its design and programming, which prioritize the task of cutting grass systematically while ensuring safety and efficiency.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, I do believe that the light behavior exhibited by the robot is important and complements its overall behavior. The fact that the mower is very accurate and observant of any object suggests that it operates with a high level of autonomy and precision. In this context, the light behavior serves as an additional feature that enhances the effectiveness and safety of the mower's operation.

past_amr_experience: I have experience and have used a floor cleaning robot, that both mops and sweeps, and after finishing its job, goes back to its charging dock.
interaction_1_describe: The mower's behaviour is most likely to mow the lawn in straight lines and at the same time detecting any obstacle on its way. The mower also looked as if it got out of the human's way in a very respectful way.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The robot is communicating a purpose of doing what it is supposed to do, which is mow the lawn and to not interfere with any human's activities.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: I think the light behaviour is very important because it lets the person know that it got detected by the robot and that the robot will not keep going and accidentally hurt someone.
interaction_2_describe: The mower in the video detects and obstacle, but instead of stopping, it keeps going to finish its job and not hurt the person walking.
interaction_2_communicating_response: The robot's purpose being communicated is that  it will keep working without hurting someone.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: The light behaviour did not change, to let the person know that it is still working.
interaction_3_describe: The mower seems to have detected the person standing and is letting them know that it wants to pass to continue working.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The mower is communicating that its purpose is to mow and communicate with people when they are in it's way.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: The light behaviour changes when the robot detected the person standing, which is important since the person standing can tell when the robot detected them and is trying to communicate something.
interaction_4_describe: The mower seems to have detected the person looking the opposite direction and goes in front of him to communicate that it is trying to mow where they are standing.
interaction_4_communicating_response: The mower is communicated with the person of its intention which is to mow where they are standing.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: It is important because the light changed and it is the robot's way of communicating with people of what it wants to do

past_amr_experience: While working in Ikea I seen logistics department using some. I work in different department so I have no interaction with the robots
interaction_1_describe: When it sees an obstacle (a man) it stops and goes out of the way to let the man walk
interaction_1_communicating_response: It's goal is to move out of the way to let the person walk.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: The behaviour is justified. The robot is programmed this way to get out of the way
interaction_2_describe: As it works, it sees an obstacle and slows down. It does this to match the obstacle speed and to not cause any problems
interaction_2_communicating_response: The robots purpose here is to continue doing it's job, But it sees and obstacle and has to slow down. Everything in robots actions is justified.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Yes, when it sees an obstacle it slows down to not hit the person.
interaction_3_describe: The mower tries to move but it sees and obstacle and attempts to do move in the same direction again, but it can't since the obstacle is still there.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think the robot is trying to overcome an obstacle, but in a wrong way. After 2 tries if the obstacle is still there, the robot should go around the obstacle. If an obstacle is a solid not moving body, the robot would never leave it's place and would be in a loop
interaction_3_light_behaviour: As mentioned earlier, this is not what I would want my robot to do. It would get stuck and a person would need to remove the obstacle or move the robot
interaction_4_describe: The mower sees an obstacle and tries to go around it. After going around it it tries to mow the same place that it missed, but it can't because the obstacle is still there.
interaction_4_communicating_response: This behaviour is much better, since the robot tries to move around the obstacle. But it still runs to the same problem, just from the other side.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Going around the obstacle was complemented, but trying to mow the place where the obstacle was is not complemented. If after a few tries it still can't mow that place it should just continue working

past_amr_experience: I have observed videos of AMRs, and interacted with AMRs at exhibitions and public events.  I do not own any AMRs, but am fascinated by technology and open to owning one or more in the future.
interaction_1_describe: The mower drives in a straight line, seemingly following a program.  Upon sensing an obstruction (human blocking it's path) the robot appears to break it's programmed routine, reverse and "politely" move itself out of the path of the human to give them priority and avoid a collision.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The human would expect the robot to move in a predictable, programmed route (e.g. straight lines between side A and side B of a space, moving slightly each time so as to cover the whole area).  With its straight movement, the robot appears to indicate it is purposely trying to cross (mow) the room.  The lights also help alert humans to its presence and the potential for collision.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes.  The light pattern change made me think the robot had acknowledged the presence of the human blocking the path.  This communicates to the human that the robot is aware of them and may react / change course in order to proceed and fulfil its programmed purpose.
interaction_2_describe: The robot intends to follow a programmed mowing route.  It detects a human in its path (an obstruction) and detects that the obstruction is moving.  The robot "politely" slows to follow the human without colliding or getting too close to the human's personal space.
interaction_2_communicating_response: The robot is programmed to complete its task of covering an area.  The human is seemingly unaware of the robot behind him and it is not making a noise to alert him.  To an observer however, the robot is clearly showing it is waiting for the human to move to make progress.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: The lights remained consist in this encounter.  The behaviour of the robot indicated it had detected and was responding to the human, but the lighting did not.  An observer would guess the robot had detected and was responding to the human through its behaviour.
interaction_3_describe: The robot intends to cross the room as it is programmed to do so.  Upon encountering a human / obstruction, the robot moves back and forth.  The robot appears to act "rudely" to the human as if saying "move out of the way" and the motor noise (sounds a bit like a revving engine) could be interpreted as frustration and impatience with the human
interaction_3_communicating_response: The robot is clearly showing its intention (and unwillingness to quit its attempts!) at crossing the room by its repeated attempts to drive "through" the human, stopping only when it gets too close.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: The lighting is less important than the robots actual behaviour in showing intention in this case. The lighting appears to confirm detection, which is shown by the stopping and reversing.
interaction_4_describe: The robot seeks to mow an area blocked by a stationary human.  Where the human is obviously unaware of the robots presence (facing away from it), the mower moves around them by some distance (which would leave a large patch of unmown grass in a lawn scenario).  The mower then attempts to mow the patch again, this time approaching from a direction where the human will surely see it.  It then flashes lights and demonstrates a "rude" revving up and down, moving backwards and forwards behaviour as if to say impatiently "move out of the way"!
interaction_4_communicating_response: The robot looks to be showing the human when in their sightline it's purpose to move into the space they occupy by its repeating attempts to occupy that space, only backing away (but immediately trying again) when detecting it has got too close.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: The lights indicate detection of the human and that the mower will do something to respond.  That it attempts to repeatedly move into the human's space again and again I feel is complemented by the flashing lights.

past_amr_experience: My experience with autonomous mobile robots so far is limited. I have randomly seen a neighbor use a vacuum robot before in his apartment, and I know that they exist and come with many handy features. However, I do not use one of myself, so I currently have little direct experience with them.
interaction_1_describe: To me it looks like the mower has recognized that a human (probably the owner?) stood in front of it. As the mower recognized the human, the mower started driving backwards and positioned itself in (what looks like to be) a parking position.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I don't think the mower is trying to send a message. What I rather think is that the mower appears to be intelligent and engaged in its "parking mode".
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, I think the blinking and strenght of the light is a helpful indicator to recognize when the robot recognized the human and switched to its parking mode. I noticed that once the roboter halted, the light also turned dim, which is useful to tell the current state / mode of the mower robot.
interaction_2_describe: The mower drives forwards and then slowly downs because of the human in front of the mower. It looks like as if the mower seems to follow the human for a while, but then stops at the yellow tape lines.
interaction_2_communicating_response: I think it's neutral here. The mower essentially does what it is supposed to do (to slow down in order to not hit a human, and to stay within its designated area).
interaction_2_light_behaviour: In this case not really, because there was no change in the light (both in intensity, pulsing, etc.)
interaction_3_describe: The mower drives towards the human, and once the mower recognized him, it repeatedly drives backwards and forwards. The LED light also changes the pattern depending on the direction.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think yes, it looks like as if the mower tries to communicate something. I'm not sure what that would be, but as it drives backwards and forwards the whole time, it appears to be waiting for an input or a reaction. Maybe it's trying to tell that the man is supposed to get out of the way?
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, the light indicated whether the robot is driving backwards or forwards (which visibly started once it recognized the man).
interaction_4_describe: The mower carefully drives around the man, rotates to face him, and then does the same back and forth driving like in the previous video; with the same LED light pulsing.
interaction_4_communicating_response: In the first half of the video I think the mower was completely autonomous. But in the second half of the video (when it started facing the man), it appears to try to tell something again through its backwards and forwards driving. Because it does not drive around the man this time, I wonder what that would be.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, but only in the second half of the video where the light indicated the driving direction.

past_amr_experience: At home I have an autonomous vacuum cleaner, and my parents have an autonomous robot they use to clean their small swimming pool. I have helped them with its configuration a couple of times, too.
interaction_1_describe: The mower seems to detect there is a moving obstacle in front of it and, I think, it "wants" to let the moving obstacle pass. I suppose it detects it's a person, not an object that cannot move.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I think the robot wants the moving obstacle to pass through, so it can retake its (the robot's) movement or route.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, I think it wanted to show the intention of the robot to change its direction and go back instead.
interaction_2_describe: The mower recognizes a moving object in front, and that this object is moving slower than itself, so it adjusts its speed not to hit the moving object (a person, in this case).
interaction_2_communicating_response: I'm not sure about this one, but I'd say that, by adjusting its speed, the robot tries to show it won't hit the person, won't put any pressure, and that it can adapt to the movements around and their speed.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Well, it shows its presence (which is important), but there is no change when the speed is lower (and don't really think it's necessary to adjust the light depending on the speed).
interaction_3_describe: This one's interesting. The mower detects a presence in front, and goes back and forward, changing the lights accordingly. However, it doesn't try to avoid or go around the obstacle, not hits it.
interaction_3_communicating_response: By changing the direction of the lights, it shows where it intends to go (backward or forward). However, the movement itself seems to try to communicate the intention of not hitting the obstacle in front (and, therefore, the presence of the obstacle).
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, since it shows the direction of the movement the robot intends to take.
interaction_4_describe: The mower goes forward until it detects a presence. It seems to know this presence/obstacle is not looking at it and may not be aware of the presence of the mower, so it goes around it, turns until it's in front of the presence and, therefore, can be seen by the presence/person. In that stage, it goes back and forward several times, showing the direction also by the change of the lights accordingly.
interaction_4_communicating_response: The purpose not to hit the person, to be within the field of vision (moreover, in front) of this person and, finally, the movement back and forward (maybe trying to say it can't go ahead anymore).
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, since it shows the intention of going backwards or forward.

past_amr_experience: No real experience
