past_amr_experience: I have worked on projects where AMRs were deployed to streamline warehouse operations. They efficiently handled tasks such as picking, packing, and transporting goods, significantly improving operational efficiency and accuracy.

past_amr_experience: I have neighbors and friends who have robotic lawnmowers and vacuum cleaners, and I have talked to them about these devices and what kind of benefits and downsides they have, and on a few occasions I have also watched as they handled and maintained them, but I have never personally owned an AMR.
interaction_1_describe: The mower encounters a human in its way, stops, its lights start to blink which indicates that it's in a different mode than previously, and it makes room for the human to pass.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The blinking lights on the mower communicates that it is in a different mode than it was previously in. I interpret the blinking as a signal because the mower encounters an obstacle and has to deviate from its path.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, because the light indicated that the mower's behavior had changed.
interaction_2_describe: The mower maintains a steady speed until it encounters a human who is moving away from it, in the same direction it is moving. As the mower gets closer it doesn't deviate from the path but slows down.
interaction_2_communicating_response: No lights are flashing and no audible signal can be heard, so I don't think the mower is trying to communicate.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: No, because there was no change in the light.
interaction_3_describe: The mower encounters a stationary human, but instead of deviating from its path, the robot backs away before attempting to move in the same direction, resulting in the mower attempting to move across the same surface multiple times. The lights on the mower indicate in which direction it is moving.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The lights on the mower flash in a way that seem to indicate in which direction it is moving. If the light flash from the back forwards, the robot is moving forwards, and if the light is flashing towards the back, the robot is backing away.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, the lights indicate to the human in which direction the mower was moving.
interaction_4_describe: The mower encounters a stationary human, deviates from the path and goes around the human. Then the robot attempts to move onto the surface where the human is standing, resulting in it backing away and moving forwards multiple times.
interaction_4_communicating_response: When the mower is moving in front of the human, the lights on it flash in a way that can be interpreted as it indicating in which direction it is moving, either forwards or backwards.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, the light was important as it indicated in which direction the mower was moving when in front of a human.

past_amr_experience: I've used some in the past, mostly vacuum cleaners

interaction_1_describe: The mower detects the person walking towards it, stops and moves aside to let that person keep walking forward.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The way the mower stopped and than immediately moved back and stepped aside, makes clear communication that it wants the person to proceed.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: In this situation I think it was only midly important to show that the mower was reacting to the person.
interaction_2_describe: The mower slowed down once it go too close to the person walking in the same direction as it.
interaction_2_communicating_response: The fact that the mower slows down shows it recognizes the person in front, but it's not super clear that the person is clear of risk from being ran over by it.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: The light behaviour was not important in this instance.
interaction_3_describe: The mower notices someone standing still and proceeds to slow down and stop, followed by accelerating forward again. He repeats this process until the person moves.
interaction_3_communicating_response: By moving back and forth in the same place the mower shows that it wants to pass, but is waiting for the person to move.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: The lighting was helpful to show the change in direction of the mower's acceleration.
interaction_4_describe: The mower recognizes someone standing still, and he understands he's facing their back, therefore he moves to their front and proceeds to move back and forth to show it wants to pass.
interaction_4_communicating_response: I think the mower's attempt at communication is quite good in this video because it moves to the front of the person to more clearly communicated the need to pass.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: The light was useful in showing the change in directions.

past_amr_experience: There is a robot vacuum cleaner at my workplace. It gets activated around 18:00 pm in the afternoon and starts doing its thing. It's pretty funny because my boss has named him Bob and when he gets stuck at furniture, he starts beeping and sends notifications to his phone asking for help.
interaction_1_describe: The mower starts following a specific path. When it meets a human being, it starts backing off and then moves out of the way for the human to pass.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The robot's intention was to move out of the way of the human, letting him pass before continuing.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Moving completely out of the way was not important,  but it emphasized the willingness to give way to the human so that he can understand that he can freely continue moving.
interaction_2_describe: The mower follows a specific path at a given speed. When it starts approaching a human, it slows down so that it doesn't hit  him.
interaction_2_communicating_response: Its purpose is to show the human that it knows he is there, and slows down instead of trying to pass him.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: It is important because it shows that the robot can evaluate a given situation and respond accordingly. In this case, it demonstrated its ability to change its pace when approaching a human being.
interaction_3_describe: This time, the mower moves forward until it meets an obstacle. It backs off and tries to move forward again, repeating this process until the obstacle is gone.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think the robot is trying to communicate that it wants to keep moving forward and tries to signal the human to move out of the way.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: It was important because it clearly communicated its intention to move forward, making it understandable that the human needs to move out of the way.
interaction_4_describe: The mower's behaviour is similar to that of the previous one, but this time it demonstrates extra functionality. It first moves forward, then goes around the human and then tries to move forward again, backing off everytime it recognises that the human hasn't moved out of the way.
interaction_4_communicating_response: The robot's purpose is to let the human know that he needs to move out of the way in order for it to continue its course.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: This behaviour was very important. The robot recognised that the human was turned the other way and couldn't see it it, so, before letting him know that he needs to move out of the way, it went around him so that it was facing him. Then started going forward and backwards until the human moves out of the way.

interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, I think the behavior shown by the robot was important because it shows that no accidents can be caused by when there are robots.
interaction_2_describe: The Mower decreases its speed because it detected the human in front of it and that is a good behavior.
interaction_2_communicating_response: As we know the purpose of a robot is to do tasks that can be done by humans but in this case it did it better than humans because a human would never tolerate such from a human.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Yes, it was important because the robot avoided an accident that could have been caused by a human.
interaction_3_describe: To me it is a good behavior, because it has indicated several times that it needs to the way to be cleared out for it to move.
interaction_3_communicating_response: With the purpose of doing the exact tasks and even more than human does, the Mower has shown the human that for it to move forward it needs the human to clear the way out.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, It was important because the robot has shown the human that it needs to move forward.
interaction_4_describe: The Mower was a bit strange this time because it went straight to the front after coming from behind the human, therefore I find its behaviour strange.
interaction_4_communicating_response: As designed the robot purpose is to do tasks traditionally done by humans so it has done so but this robot seems like it was given an order.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, I think the robot completed its behaviour because it was behind the human but ended up in front of the human.

past_amr_experience: I have a robot vacuum cleaner that I use on a weekly basis that falls into this category.
interaction_1_describe: It senses and predicts the behavior of another moving body, interpreting that it is the mower that needs to move aside in order for the other body to continue its previous trajectory. Probably, it is able to identify the other body as a human being or living being (we would have to see how it behaves with a dog).
interaction_1_communicating_response: It is only obeying its programming, it must step aside when the body in front of it meets certain requirements.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: It is complementary for the human interacting for the robot, as it indicates where it will move to, not for the robot itself
interaction_2_describe: The mower identifies the moving body in front of it and adjusts its speed to avoid collision
interaction_2_communicating_response: Does not communicate anything beyond speed change
interaction_2_light_behaviour: no
interaction_3_describe: The mower has run into an obstacle and are starting to go backwards and forwards, without really solving the problem.
interaction_3_communicating_response: communicates the direction in which it will move with its lights, but nothing else.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: it communicates the direction of movement, so it was complementary
interaction_4_describe: the mower encountered an obstacle, went around it, returned to the delimited area and then encountered the same obstacle again. From there it could no longer solve the problem.
interaction_4_communicating_response: only the lights to indicate it's direction of movement
interaction_4_light_behaviour: again, important only to the human who sees it, so it is complementary.

past_amr_experience: I owned an iRobot Roomba for a while. Also, I bought some robots as gifts.
interaction_1_describe: The moving robot recognized the approaching person. It stopped about half a meter before the person. Then, it moved aside and passed the person to walk by.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I couldn't recognize any attempts of communication. Maybe the side lights meant to show something. However, there was no in-front view to see if blinking lights meant the mower would turn right.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Maybe. From the presented view, it was hard to see if blinking appeared only on one side of the robot, indicating that it would turn right. Nevertheless, the mower turned right but by moving backward. A more common way for turning is turning with moving forward.
interaction_2_describe: The moving mower decreased its speed after approaching a person from behind. It adapted its speed to the speed of the person in front.
interaction_2_communicating_response: I haven't noticed anything regarding communication from the mower.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: No. I haven't seen any changes in the lights' behavior.
interaction_3_describe: The mower approached a standing person. It stopped about half a meter from the person and then moved back and forth a bit. During moving, the side lights blinked (waved) similarly as if it would like to turn. However, the mover didn't turn.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The mower seemed to want to show its intention, but it wasn't clear to me at all.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: The light behavior was supposed to communicate something, but it wasn't clear and provided no information.
interaction_4_describe: The mower approached the standing person from behind, bypassed her, and approached the person from the front. Then, it behaved similarly to the earlier clip. Presumably, its behavior was intended to force the person to move away and allow it to continue working.
interaction_4_communicating_response: Based on previous clips, I assume that the blinking lights and moving back and forth were meant to communicate to the person to move away.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, the light behavior was important and somehow complemented the mower's behavior.

past_amr_experience: I own a Roomba vacuum cleaner since 3 years and a lawn mower in my garden since 2 years
interaction_1_describe: It slowly approaches the selected area and stops whenever it detects an obstacle
interaction_1_communicating_response: I think it stopped to secure the area after detecting an unwanted obstacle
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes I think the lightning means obstacle detected and the blue light means standby
interaction_2_describe: The device slowed down its movement, but when the obstacle cleared the area, it was able to complete its path
interaction_2_communicating_response: The robot slowed down because of the obstacle but could complete its path whenever the area was cleared
interaction_2_light_behaviour: No, it was the normal still light
interaction_3_describe: The robot tries to complete the path, but the fixed obstacle prevents it from continuing despite repeated attempts
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think it's trying to communicate what the established route is, attempting to induce the obstacle to move, in case it's not a fixed obstacle
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, I believe the continuous flashing of the light intends to communicate the detected obstacle and the ongoing movement
interaction_4_describe: This was a weird behaviour, a combination of the previous ones, but I didn't expect it to go out of the selected area to avoid the obstacle

interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, but only when the light starts flashing it attempts to communicate the movement towards the obstacle, meaning it can be dangerous being around it

past_amr_experience: I have a robot vacuum in my house. I also frequently go to a Mcdonald's near my house that has a robot waitress.
interaction_1_describe: The mower takes notice that a person has approached it and backtracks to leave space for the human to walk and get out of the way.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The mower's action to backtrack has the intention of clearing the way for the person. Just like a human would take a step back at a grocery store to leave space for another person to walk.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes. It was a smart choice. Although I feel like this could be a problem since I'm not sure how close it could get to mowing grass that's near walls
interaction_2_describe: The mower identifies that a person is in front of it and slows down to not crash into them.
interaction_2_communicating_response: It's clear that the robot only slowed down to avoid colliding with the person in front of it. The intention was clear.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Yes. It's a good tool. It doesn't completely stop, but just adjusts the speed.
interaction_3_describe: The mower backtracks when it perceives an object (a person, in this case) in the middle of the road. But immediately reattempts to continue.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The reattempting from the robot can be very useful because sometimes there might be pets or people that are walking around the garden but the mower wouldn't know that they left if it doesn't try to reattempt. Good feature.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes. As explained above, this is a necessary feature for robots.
interaction_4_describe: The mower has identified a person standing in a fixed position. It circles around the person and tries again.
interaction_4_communicating_response: The intention was clear and obvious.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, it's great that it avoids big objects or people to avoid crashing onto them.

past_amr_experience: My mother owns a Roomba, and my brother explained to me a little bit about how it works. Otherwise, I have never owned one of these AMRs myself.
interaction_1_describe: The mower is moving in a straight line across the floor, but stops when it encounters an obstacle- in this case, a person. Once it stops, it backs up and moves off to the side, as if to let the person by to continue walking.
interaction_1_communicating_response: It appears to me that the robot understands that the obstacle in question is a living being, or at the very least, something that is in motion and wants to continue moving. The robot moves off to the side as if to let the moving object continue on its path before resuming mowing,
interaction_1_light_behaviour: I think it is important. It demonstrates that the robot can potentially differentiate between living and non-living beings, or at least between a stationary object and a moving one. This will help it to avoid causing damage while mowing the lawn, where it could encounter a variety of different obstacles.
interaction_2_describe: The mower begins by moving in a straight line across the floor, but pauses when it encounters the person, and slows its speed to match that of the person when they begin to walk forward while remaining directly in front of the mower.
interaction_2_communicating_response: I think the robot is showing that it understands that there is something ahead of it that is moving at a fixed pace, and so it slows to match the pace. It still needs to continue mowing that part of the "lawn", but can do so at a slower pace to accommodate the object in motion in front of it.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: This is important because it again demonstrates that it recognizes when there is an object in motion, and work to accommodate this while still performing its task.
interaction_3_describe: The mower beings by moving forward in a straight line, but stops and reverses a small distance when it encounters a person. It attempts to continue moving forward, but the person remains in their spot, so the mower reverses again and attempts to move forward again. It repeats this action on a loop several times.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The mower appears to be attempting to communicate that it needs to continue performing its task, but is unable to do so due to the obstacle in front of it. It could potentially be perceiving the person as standing on a patch of "grass" that needs to be mowed.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: I think the importance that comes from this is that the robot appears to be demonstrating the knowledge that it knows when an object in front of them is something that CAN move, but won't. Otherwise it would attempt to move around the object. Or, potentially, that it knows when there is a location that needs to be mowed but cannot access it for one reason or another.
interaction_4_describe: The mower begins by moving forward in a straight line until it encounters a person, but continues on around the person and loops back to the other side of them. When it encounters the person again, it begins to reverse and then move forward several times, stopping in front of the person each time.
interaction_4_communicating_response: This to me appears more that the mower recognizes and area that it needs to mow but cannot access. It continues to mow areas of the "lawn" that it recognizes needs to be mowed, and then circles back around to see if their obstacle is still in its place.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: It is important in the sense that it highlights the robot's knowledge of the areas that it needs to mow, but otherwise, this behavior seems fairly similar to what was performed in the previous video, and even shows that the robot may not be quite as intuitive as previously assumed, because the robot doesn't appear to be able to recognize when an object can or cannot move.

past_amr_experience: I see them a lot in the area I live in. They're usually purchased by the landlords and house owners in residential areas in my part of the city (Aarhus, Denmark). So I don't have personal experience owning an autonomous lawnmower, but I see them a lot all over the place.
interaction_1_describe: The mower was going in a straight line towards the person walking.  Basically on a "colision course". It seemed like it sensed the person coming, reversed and pulled over to let the person pass.
interaction_1_communicating_response: It seems like the mower has been programmed to give way for people. That is reverse when it's senses a person coming in its path and giving way.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: I didn't really pay much attention to it. So I guess it was important, now you've asked a question about it. But it was the behaviour (stopping, reversing, pulling over) that I took notice of. Not the lights.
interaction_2_describe: The mower was going in the same path as the person. Once it came within a certain range of the person it slowed down to match the person's speed.
interaction_2_communicating_response:
Here it's not as crystal clear to me (like in the previous video) that the mower was adjusting its behaviour to account for the person. Probably because only the speed of the mower changed. It didn't make any other manuveurs to avoid the person.
That said it's clear it slowed down to not run into the person.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: I focused more on the lights at the start of the video, since I figured you'd ask me the same question as the previous video, but I lost focus of it once the mower started slowing down. So no, it didn't complement the behaviour in a sense that I would easily be able to interpret it.
interaction_3_describe: The mower has noticed a person standing in its path and attempts to reverse and move forward. Doing this several times.
interaction_3_communicating_response: Here it seems like the robot is aware there's an obstacle in place, but this obstacle doesn't have to be a human, it could just be some debris or a rock or something else. To me it seems like it's stuck in a loop it can't get out of, because there's an obstacle in the way.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Here I actually noticed that the light was flashing once it encountered the person/obstacle. So in that sense I'd say it was important. However, I'm probably biased now, because I know you're asking the question, so I'm more focused on it. So take it with a grain of salt.
interaction_4_describe: Here the mower is going along a path and encounters a person/obstacle. it slowly moves off track and avoids the obstacle. However, it then turns around and tries to drive back on the same path, where the person/obstacle still is.
interaction_4_communicating_response: I can't really tell here, because the mower is obviously slowing down and moving around the person/obstacle to avoid it. Which seems like smart behaviour. However, the mower then turns around and tries to return to the path it came from and starts driving forward, reversing, driving forward, reversing. Now it's not communication a purpose, rather stuck in a loop.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: This time I didn't pay attention to it at all, even though I knew the question was coming. So no.

interaction_1_describe: The mower detected a person and positioned itself to allow the person to pass according to the route he was taking.
interaction_1_communicating_response: The purpose of the robot would be to indicate the stand-by state after encountering an obstacle.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, it shows that there was a change in the state of the robot
interaction_2_describe: The mower detects the presence of an obstacle, in this case, a human, and is able to understand that he is moving, so it does not need to stop completely, but rather slow down to avoid colliding.
interaction_2_communicating_response: I think the robot is just following its path depending on the obstacles it encounters
interaction_2_light_behaviour: In this case, the light never changed, so it doesn't make sense.
interaction_3_describe: The mower encountered a human, backed up, and moved forward repeatedly, possibly to warn the human to get out of the way.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I think the robot's behavior indicates that it is trying to send a message to the human to deviate.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes, the change in the robot's light captures the human's attention, alerting him and can also indicate it status.
interaction_4_describe: The mower finds an obstacle and goes around it, returning to the path it was supposed to take.
interaction_4_communicating_response: I think that the purpose of the mower is to inform the human to deviate so that he can pass through the area where he is.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, the light alerts the human and also indicates the status of the robot.

past_amr_experience: My family has owned a robot vacuum in the past. It faced a lot of issues (getting stuck for no reason/no obstacles, not cleaning as much as a regular vacuum). For this reason, I did not buy one for my home.
interaction_1_describe: The mower appears to have noticed the person, and stopped in time (though the person was moving slowly, maybe if they were moving faster, it wouldn't have had time to stop). It backed up for them to make way, so it appears to be programmed to prioritise humans over its "job."
interaction_1_communicating_response: I think its purpose is to mow 2nd, and human safety 1st, since it stopped its course as soon as it sensed the person, and backed up to make way for them too (something that maybe wasn't completely necessary in this case).
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Constant lighting indicated movement. Light then changed to indicate the mower backing up (light went the same direction). Then when the mower stopped, the light did too. So yes, I would say the light behaviour of the robot is important to understanding its behaviour.
interaction_2_describe: Person was in the way of the mower, but began moving before the mower reached them. The mower appears to have sensed that, and did not stop (as it was not needed), but slowed down instead and kept its course.
interaction_2_communicating_response: It kept its course but did not put the person in danger, and neither did it stop. It appears to have understood that there was no need for stopping, as the "obstacle" started moving, so it kept its course/purpose, and adjusted accordingly.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: The light did not change at all. Judging by the video, the light remained the same as the course/action of the mower remained the same as well. It did not indicate the mower slowing down, but the fact that it remained as is shows clearly that the mower was not changing its course/direction, only its speed.
interaction_3_describe: The mower encountered a person/obstacle, and attempted to back up, giving the obstacle space. The person did not move, so the mower appeared to be stuck in a "back-and-forth" cycle.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The mower's "intentions" are clear in this video. It stopped in time for it to not hit the person. Then it attempted to give space to the person to move, while indicating its course of action via its lights (the person could tell when the mower would go back or forth).
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Light behaviour was very clear and important here. The lighting changing as soon as it encounters the person showcased the mower "noticing" the person. Then the direction of the light indicated clearly where the mower was going and what it was doing (backwards direction to show the mower was backing up, and vice versa).
interaction_4_describe: At first the mower appears to have sensed the person/obstacle, and just went around them instead of getting stuck. But on its way back, it seemed to have been stuck on the same "back-and-forth" cycle as before.
interaction_4_communicating_response: If I had to guess by the mower's behaviour, it seems that at first it perceived the person not as a human, but as an immovable obstacle; hence making the decision to go around it, as it would not move. But when facing the person it perceived them as a human, therefore backing up and giving the person space to move/leave.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: The lighting behaviour was clear and important, as in all previous videos. The direction of the light and whether it changed or not showcased clearly what the mower was about to do - or not do (at first it did not change its course of action, as it kept moving forward, only its direction, as it went around the person without stopping)

past_amr_experience: I have used products like irobot, which are household cleaning products.
interaction_1_describe: The movement of the robot feels fluid and detects the presence of the person well, however I thought that when turning the robot it was a little clumsy.
interaction_1_communicating_response: It seems to me that the purpose of communication is to say that the robot detects obstacles around it and that it is also safe with the presence of people in its work area.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: It seems to me that the lighting support for communication is good, although the color and lighting mode may not be the most appropriate, it should be clearer.
interaction_2_describe: The movement seemed good to me, that is, slowing down while detecting a person in front.
interaction_2_communicating_response: It communicates that the product is safe and has the ability to detect the movement of a person and adapt their movement while they are close to their work area.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: It is not important because in reality there is no communication through lighting, it should have a lighting mode while detecting a moving person.
interaction_3_describe: The movement appears to be moving closer and farther away to calculate the distance between it and the person.
interaction_3_communicating_response: Although the movement at the beginning seems to be calculating the distance from the person, it seemed to me that it had a hard time calculating the route again.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: It is important because it shows different lighting than normal navigation mode.
interaction_4_describe: Movement is about detecting an obstacle, calculating it and generating a new navigation route to your next obstacle.
interaction_4_communicating_response: The purpose is to show the robot's ability to detect an obstacle and generate a new route to avoid it without hitting it.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: It seemed to me that the light behavior is not consistent when being close to an obstacle, at the beginning there was no light communication and at the end there was.

past_amr_experience: Own a robotic hoover and use daily.
interaction_1_describe: The lawn mower was in the same path as a person and when it got too close it didnt take priority and moved out of the way so the person could continue on their path.
interaction_1_communicating_response: It is communicating that the persons needs are more important than its own.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes it was important but also makes it a less efficient lawn mower.
interaction_2_describe: When the lawn mower came close to the person it slowed down in speed.
interaction_2_communicating_response: It is trying to not crash into the person but still completing the job.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Yes it still does its job but doesnt get in the way of the person.
interaction_3_describe: The lawn mower is repeatedly trying to get past the person but cant so is stuck in a loop of back and forth.
interaction_3_communicating_response: The robot is trying to go forward but is struggling.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Yes it shows the person they need to move as it cant get around them.
interaction_4_describe: The robot knows theres an obstacle but is able to map them out and go around them.
interaction_4_communicating_response: It is showing it is going around the person but still completing the task.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes its showing it is thinking and going against the pre programmed next step and doing something different due to the person.

past_amr_experience: I have only seen ads and reviews of these products, not had a chance to use nay first hand
interaction_1_describe: The mover displays a kind of intelligence where it senses that there's someone in its path and decides to let them go first before proceeding.
interaction_1_communicating_response: I believe by the robot giving space and going to the side lets the person know that they should be able to pass before the mower can resume its duties

interaction_2_describe: The mower tends to follow the lead of the person ahead and follows in their path

interaction_2_light_behaviour: No, I don't think the light was important in this scenario
interaction_3_describe: I think the mower is trying to communicate to the person in front of it that they are in the path of the mower. This is displayed by the back and forth movement and lighting pattern
interaction_3_communicating_response: The back and forth movement of the robot is likely intended to portray to the person looking at it to step aside from the path of the robot

interaction_4_describe: The mower is likely trying to get around in to the sight of the person who was in its path and tries to inform them of that fact

past_amr_experience: I have never owned one. But I know quite a lot of people who has one. One time we talked about one at a family gathering, and they told me about how they had to set it up, and just how it worked in general.
interaction_1_describe: It goes forward until it "sees" a person. Then it backs up and turns to the side, so the person can pass by.
interaction_1_communicating_response: It clearly goes back to make room for the person to pass by.
interaction_1_light_behaviour: I honestly didn't notice the light when I watched the video the first time. Then after I read this question, I went back and watched it again to see it. I think the light is a good addiction, and it signals that it has detected the person.
interaction_2_describe: I "sees" that it coming close to a person who is moving away for the mower. But the mower is going at a faster speed, so it slows down.
interaction_2_communicating_response: It slows down when it got close, and gets a bit quieter which suggests that it's slowing down. But there are now difference in the lights or anything.
interaction_2_light_behaviour: The light didn't change. But in this case it didn't need to, as the person was walking away looking the other way.
interaction_3_describe: The mower moves up to the person, the detects him and backs up.  Then it continues to move back and forth, presumably until it's path is clear.
interaction_3_communicating_response: I guess it just seems like it wants to get past the person.
interaction_3_light_behaviour: I starts blinking when it gets close to the person, thereby alerting that it has seen him.
interaction_4_describe: It starts by driving around the person. Then it turns back towards the person wanting and moves back and forth in front of the person.
interaction_4_communicating_response: It moved it infront of the person, and started signalling that it wanted the person to move, so it could mow the spot he was on.
interaction_4_light_behaviour: It started blinking when it was in front of the person. Thereby signalling that it sees him.

past_amr_experience: AMRs are fascinating robots and machines that help us with our daily lives and make tasks easier, i personally have a AMR vacum roomba, which help me keep my floors clean, i save around 30 minutes every day not needing to clean as much thanks to my roomba
interaction_1_describe: It appears to stop, back up and move to the side, making it so the human does not need to move from its path, instead the mower does it for him
interaction_1_communicating_response: I believe the robots intention is to not appear as an obstacle or something that you have to be careful and avoid, i believe with its action it did it makes you feel more comfortable with it around
interaction_1_light_behaviour: Yes, i think its necessary to show that AMR are advancing fast and are not seen as objects that bother you or impeed you from moving
interaction_2_describe: It appears to slow down and match the speed the person is walking.
interaction_2_communicating_response: Its intention is to respect the user and make it so its more than just a robot, it seems that the robot is willing to respect the speed of the people around them in order to not startle them
interaction_2_light_behaviour: Yes, once again its important to show that these robots are more than just simple machines and that they learn from surroundings
interaction_3_describe: It appears to go back and forth in front of the person, maybe to get its attention but it didnt move to the side like the the other demostration
interaction_3_communicating_response: I dont really know what its trying to say, maybe "Hey im working here, can you please move" but once again, its unclear
interaction_3_light_behaviour: Kind of, i think it wants to say to move to the side, but i not really sure
interaction_4_describe: It appears to go around the user if it sees that its back is facing it, but once it sees that the person is standing in front of it it does the moving back and forth again and again
interaction_4_communicating_response: I think the robots thinks that how you're not looking at it, it'll go around you, but once it knows you're facing it and know it's there it wants you to move
interaction_4_light_behaviour: Yes, kinda of, its good that the robot knows what way the person is facing that way it can avoid accidents, but the moving back and forth still doesnt give me a good answer on whats its trying to do
